1067471302984957952.text:
the primer ends with a sort of call-to-action for the industry: smart contract "Governance standards...could create presumptions regarding the legal
character of a smart contract, depending on its attributes and
manner of use by market participants." Better clarity can be reached

1067468496773226497.text: beyond that, a smart contract's "application or product characterization" can subject it to a bevy of legal frameworks, including (i) Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), (ii) AML regulations, and (iii) State and federal money transmission laws (see slide 25 for fulsome list)

1067467122379554816.text: CFTC also suggests that smart contracts may be a 'binding legal contract'. This reminds me of @michaelrice's work, formulating 'Legal, Solidity Based Smart Contracts':https://medium.com/@michaelriceLE/introducing-a-new-project-a-collection-of-legal-solidity-based-smart-contracts-6d6b534e193 …

1067466433318322177.text: now this is language that I haven't seen yet, good stuff: "Contracts or **constituent parts of contracts that are written in code** are subject to otherwise applicable law and regulation."

1067465787311558658.text:
CFTC notes that 'depending on its structure, operation, and relevant facts and circumstances, a smart contract could be a: 
• Commodity
• Forward Contract
• Futures Contract
• Option on Futures Contract
• Swap' 
 - -& therefore, may be 'product subject to CFTC jurisdiction'

1067464868813570049.text: As for the kicker, "The Role of the CFTC", the agency notes its mission to 'foster open, transparent, competitive, and financially sound markets' and that 'responsible innovation is market-enhancing', further:

1067463587483013121.text: The CFTC further outlines various 'smart contract use cases,' including applications to improve efficiency and speed of Trade Clearing & Settlement; streamline tracking and payments for Supply Chain/Trade Finance

1067462075448999937.text: From this context, CFTC views smart contracts as "part of an evolution to automate processes with machines and self-executing code", and notes increasing automation in financial markets (e.g., 'trading algorithms') and everyday life (e.g., 'automatic bill pay')

1067461179705053186.text: CFTC also notes that the "concept of a smart contract is not new," and cites work by @NickSzabo4 on this subject "more than 20 years ago"; also includes viewpoints of @VitalikButerin & @kwerb on how to define "smart contracts" (slide 9)

1067459988568899586.text: CFTC breaks smart contracts down into 3 key attributes: (i) Digital Signatures ('verify participation and assent'), (ii) Oracles ('mutually agreed upon, network-authenticated reference data provider'), and (iii) Self-Execution ('without further action by counterparties')

1067458519262216192.text: CFTC starts off by noting that 'smart' may be a bit of misnomer here: "the operation is only as smart as the information feed it receives and the machine code that directs it"

1067455550596751366.text: hot off the presses, “A CFTC Primer on Smart Contracts”: https://www.cftc.gov/sites/default/files/2018-11/LabCFTC_PrimerSmartContracts112718.pdf …
